{"uri": "8185480606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:28:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:28:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:25:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://kion546.com/ap-national/2024/06/19/hundreds-died-during-this-years-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-amid-intense-heat-officials-say/", "title": "Hundreds died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia amid intense heat, officials say - KION546", "body": "MECCA, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil,\n\nAt the Grand Mosque in Mecca, temperatures reached 51.8 C (125 F) on Monday though pilgrims had already left for Mina, authorities said.\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the causes of death for those bodies held at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press religion coverage receives support through the AP's collaboration with The Conversation US, with funding from Lilly Endowment Inc. {"uri": "8185989964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:49:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:49:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:48:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/hundreds-died-during-this-years-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-amid-intense-heat/JAYBAGLELFH6HALVG2OC7FTZQQ/", "title": "Intense heat kills hundreds at Muslim pilgrimage", "body": "Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said this week as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighbourhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity for the same reason said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility.\n\nDeaths are not uncommon at the Hajj, which has seen at times more than two million people travel to Saudi Arabia. There have also been stampedes and epidemics through the pilgrimage's history.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care\", according to an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom save their entire lives for the pilgrimage and can be elderly with pre-existing health conditions, it said.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the fatalities to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nKhalid Bashir Bazaz, an Indian pilgrim, speaking near the Grand Mosque, said he \"saw a lot of people collapsing to the ground unconscious\" during this year's Hajj.\n\nTemperatures reached 47C in Mecca this week and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Some people fainted while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nMany Egyptians said they lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nAt the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man broke down when he heard his mother was among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling their travel agent.\n\n\"He left her to die,\" he shouted, referring to the agent. The crowd tried to calm him down.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the causes of death for the people whose bodies were held at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca, home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. By 2029, the Hajj will occur in April, and in the next several years after that it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed more than 2400 pilgrims in the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, according to an AP count. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede.\n\nA separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster that same year, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1426 people.", "source": {"uri": "nzherald.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "NZ Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185380853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:20:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:20:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:19:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.etvbharat.com/en/!international/hundreds-died-during-this-year-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-amid-intense-heat-enn24061905615", "title": "Hundreds Died During This Year's Hajj Pilgrimage In Saudi Arabia Amid Intense Heat", "body": "Mecca: Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said on Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care, an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with pre-existing health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia. Temperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities. On Wednesday, at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: He left her to die! The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased. The AP could not independently confirm the cause of death at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult. Climate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an extreme danger threshold from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder. A 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.", {"uri": "2024-06-394701691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:37:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:37:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:27:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/hundreds-died-during-this-years-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-amid-intense-heat-officials-say/", "title": "Hundreds died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia amid intense heat, officials say", "body": "MECCA, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil,\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the cause of death at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press religion coverage receives support through the AP's collaboration with The Conversation US, with funding from Lilly Endowment Inc. The AP is solely responsible for this content.", "source": {"uri": "seattletimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Seattle Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "samy_magdy@seattletimes.com", "name": "Samy Magdy", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajj", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Hajj"}}, {"uri": "https://images.seattletimes.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/urnpublicidap.org706730deb869a253b819c435350a4a97APTOPIX_Saudi_Arabia_Hajj_25053.jpg?d=1020x680", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": {"uri": "8185435225", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:55:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:55:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:54:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.greenfieldreporter.com/2024/06/19/hundreds-died-during-this-years-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-amid-intense-heat-officials-say/", "title": "Hundreds died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia amid intense heat, officials say - The Daily Reporter - Greenfield Indiana", "body": "MECCA, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility.\n\nDeaths aren't uncommon at the hajj, which has drawn at times over 2 million people to Saudi Arabia. There have been stampedes and epidemics through the pilgrimage's history.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil,\n\nAt the Grand Mosque in Mecca, temperatures reached 51.8 C (125 F) on Monday though pilgrims had already left for Mina, authorities said.\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the causes of death for those bodies held at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press religion coverage receives support through the AP's collaboration with The Conversation US, with funding from Lilly Endowment Inc. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil,\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the cause of death at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed to this report.\n\nAssociated Press religion coverage receives support through the AP's collaboration with The Conversation US, with funding from Lilly Endowment Inc. "https://dims.apnews.com/dims4/default/b88fc89/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5102x2870+0+266/resize/1440x810!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.apnews.com%2F4e%2Fe2%2F4b25baf655a7aec38ce36946ff53%2F9fd567bc23ea42e6b7d9f80b0179a3c7", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9660565", "eventUri": "eng-9660565", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Mecca"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Saudi Arabia"}}}, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2862745098039216, "wgt": 216, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-394714436", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:49:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:49:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:38:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://internewscast.com/local-news/tragic-loss-of-lives-amid-sweltering-heat-at-this-years-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-reports-officials/", "title": "Tragic Loss of Lives Amid Sweltering Heat at This Year's Hajj Pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia, Reports Officials - Internewscast Journal", "body": "MECCA - Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil,\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the cause of death at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press religion coverage receives support through the AP's collaboration with The Conversation US, with funding from Lilly Endowment Inc. {"uri": "2024-06-394707106", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:42:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:42:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-06-19/hundreds-died-during-this-years-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-amid-intense-heat-officials-say", "title": "Hundreds Died During This Year's Hajj Pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia Amid Intense Heat, Officials Say", "body": "MECCA, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil,\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the cause of death at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press religion coverage receives support through the AP's collaboration with The Conversation US, with funding from Lilly Endowment Inc. The AP is solely responsible for this content.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-395791227", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:04:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:04:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:58:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/over-1000-hajj-pilgrims-die-of-heatwave-as-mercury-soars-in-saudi-arabia", "title": "Over 1000 Hajj Pilgrims Die of Heatwave As Mercury Soars in Saudi Arabia", "body": "Hajj: Over 1000 pilgrims succumbed to the heatwave in Saudi Arabia this year due to extreme temperatures. Saudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in the Al-Muaisem neighbourhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nAt least 550 Die During 5-Day Hajj\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility.\n\nThe list offered no cause of death. Each year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said.\n\nCommunicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nMecca Touches 47 Degrees Celsius\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil,\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nMan Collapses After Learning Mother's Death Due To Heatwave\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of his mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nOver 600 Indian Nationals Succumb to Heat\n\n68 Indian nationals died during the hajj pilgrimage this year marked by searing heat, bringing the overall tally to more than 600.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the cause of death at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater.\n\nA 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede.\n\nA separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people. The second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people. {"uri": "8187078740", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:07:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:07:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:05:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://religionnews.com/?p=4154188&preview=true&preview_id=4154188", "title": "Hundreds died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia amid intense heat, officials say", "body": "MECCA, Saudi Arabia (AP) -- Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity for the same reason said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility.\n\nDeaths are not uncommon at the Hajj, which has seen at times over 2 million people travel to Saudi Arabia. There have also been stampedes and epidemics through the pilgrimage's history.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" according to an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom save their entire lives for the pilgrimage and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, it said.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the fatalities to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nKhalid Bashir Bazaz, an Indian pilgrim, speaking near the Grand Mosque on Wednesday, said he \"saw a lot of people collapsing to the ground unconscious\" during this year's Hajj.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Some people fainted while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nMany Egyptians said they lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man broke down when he heard his mother was among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling their travel agent.\n\n\"He left her to die,\" he shouted, referring to the agent. The crowd tried to calm him down.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the causes of death for the people whose bodies were held at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca, home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. By 2029, the Hajj will occur in April, and in the next several years after that it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, according to an AP count. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster that same year, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Jon Gambrell in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press religion coverage receives support through the AP's collaboration with The Conversation US, with funding from Lilly Endowment Inc. The AP is solely responsible for this content.", "source": {"uri": "religionnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Religion News Service"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@religionnews.com", One medic said that the names listed appeared genuine.\n\nThat medic and another official said they believed at least 600 bodies were being stored at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nCommunicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with pre-existing health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of intense heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47C in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Centre for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his mobile phone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites.\n\nLike Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed.\n\nSaudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.", {"uri": "8185332762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:53:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:53:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:48:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-hundreds-died-during-this-years-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-amid-intense-heat-officials-say-6049549.html", "title": "World News | Hundreds Died During This Year's Hajj Pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia Amid Intense Heat, Officials Say | LatestLY", "body": "Mecca, Jun 19 (AP) Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said on Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died.\n\nAlso Read | Indian Millionaires Migration 2024: About 4,300 Millionaire To Leave India This Year and Go to Other Countries, Says Report.\n\nHowever, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighbourhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nAlso Read | Chad Ammunition Depot Fire Pics and Videos: Many Dead, Several Injured After Major Blaze Triggered by Explosion Erupts at Military Weapons and Ammunition Depot in N'Djamena.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the cause of death at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil,\n\nAt the Grand Mosque in Mecca, temperatures reached 51.8 C (125 F) on Monday though pilgrims had already left for Mina, authorities said.\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the causes of death for those bodies held at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 {"uri": "8186420950", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:11:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:11:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:05:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/world-news/20240620/hundreds-die-during-hajj-pilgrimage-amid-intense-heat", "title": "Hundreds die during Hajj pilgrimage amid intense heat", "body": "Muslim pilgrims use umbrellas to shield themselves from the sun as they arrive to cast stones at pillars in the symbolic stoning of the Devil, the last rite of the annual hajj, in Mina, near the holy city of Mecca, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday.\n\nHundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said on Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighbourhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press (AP) on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government, said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility.\n\nDeaths aren't uncommon at the Hajj, which has drawn at times over two million people to Saudi Arabia. There have been stampedes and epidemics through the pilgrimage's history.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre- Hajj healthcare,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips, and can be elderly with pre-existing health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Meteorology. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the Devil,\n\nAt the Grand Mosque in Mecca, temperatures reached 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) on Monday, though pilgrims had already left for Mina, authorities said.\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of his mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cell phone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the causes of death for those bodies held at the complex. {"uri": "8185377068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:18:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:18:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:17:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/hajj-deaths-2024-pilgrimage-mecca-heat-stampede-b2565315.html", "title": "Hundreds of Hajj pilgrims die as temperatures touch 51 degrees in Saudi Arabia", "body": "Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as temperatures have touched 51 degrees Celsius.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed there were at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\nAt least 323 of those who died were Egyptians, most of them succumbing to heat-related illnesses, two Arab diplomats coordinating their countries' responses told AFP. \"All of them [the Egyptians] died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said. One hundred and forty-four Indonesian citizens died during Hajj, according to data the Indonesian health ministry shared with Reuters on Tuesday. The data did not clarify if any of the deaths were due to heat stroke.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said.\n\nTemperatures hit 51.8C at the Grand Mosque in Mecca on Monday, the Saudi national meteorology centre said. On Tuesday, the mercury reached 47 degrees Celsius. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nOthers, including many Egyptians, lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims have performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his mobile phone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the cause of death at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites. Like Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's Mosque in the nearby city of Medina.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.", "https://static.independent.co.uk/2024/06/19/13/APTOPIX_Saudi_Arabia_Hajj_25053.jpg?quality=75&width=1200&auto=webp", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9660565", "eventUri": "eng-9660565",
