{"uri": "8187267373", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:07:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:07:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:06:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.dw.com/en/who-or-what-is-responsible-for-hajj-deaths-in-saudi-arabia/a-69428991", "title": "Who or what is responsible for Hajj deaths?", "body": "As the death toll rises, debate is raging over whether bad organization, weather or gate-crashing pilgrims are to blame for more than 1,000 deaths in Saudi Arabia during the annual Hajj religious gathering.\n\nArabic-language social media has been flooded this week with shocking images from Saudi Arabia. The pictures and videos show people who were undertaking their once-in-a-lifetime Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca collapsed on the side of the road or slumped in wheelchairs, apparently close to death or dead. They are dressed in traditional pilgrim's white, their faces covered with cloths. In several pictures, corpses appear to have been left where they presumably collapsed.\n\nWhat started as a rumor on social media was confirmed as the weeklong Hajj pilgrimage ended: Hundreds of pilgrims have died in Saudi Arabia, evidently due to extremely high temperatures and lack of shelter or water.\n\nTemperatures in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, rose to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) during the course of the annual event, which started late last week.\n\nAround 1.8 million Muslims from all over the world had been expected in Saudi Arabia to perform Hajj. One of the world's largest religious gatherings, the Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam. Every Muslim who is able to is supposed to perform it at least once in their lifetime.\n\nSources in the Saudi Arabian Health Ministry told Reuters news agency they had recorded 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion.\" But they had been speaking before reports of deaths began to emerge. The country has not updated official statistics since then.\n\nAccording to AFP news agency, which has been tallying up fatalities via different sources and countries over the past few days, the death toll has topped 1,000.\n\nPilgrims from Egypt, Indonesia, Senegal, Jordan, Iran, Iraq, India and Tunisia have all died, their governments reported. A large number, likely over 300, came from Egypt. The Indonesian Health Ministry also reported over 140 nationals' deaths.\n\nOver the past years, Saudi authorities have tried to take measures to mitigate the impact of high summer temperatures on visitors by providing things like misting stations and water dispensers. Nevertheless, it is thought that most of the recent deaths are likely heat-related. Many of the pilgrims who perform Hajj are elderly, as undertaking the Hajj is something they want to do before they die.\n\nThe death toll may continue to rise. Friends and families are still searching Saudi hospitals or putting out calls for help on social media to try to find loved ones who arrived in Mecca but who are now missing.\n\n\"Honestly, Hajj this year was shameful,\" Ihlsa, a pilgrim from Aswan, in southern Egypt, who preferred not to give her full name, told DW via WhatsApp. \"It was very difficult, especially during the stoning. People were just collapsed on the ground.\"\n\nPart of the Hajj ritual involves pilgrims throwing stones at three walls, a symbolic form of \"stoning the devil.\"\n\n\"Several times I told the security personnel about a pilgrim who had fallen onto the ground,\" Ihlsa said. \"The distance to throw the stones was really too far and at the same time the sun was high, and it was so hot.\"\n\nIn the pilgrims' home countries, a furious debate is taking place about who is to blame.\n\nTo do the Hajj, pilgrims need to have official permission from Saudi Arabia to enter the country. Because more Muslims want to come than there is space for, Saudi Arabia runs a quota system every year. Overcrowding and overheating have been serious problems in the past.\n\nThe trip to Saudi Arabia is usually facilitated by travel agencies, often linked to Muslim community organizations or mosques back home. They organize accommodation, food and transport in Mecca. Registered pilgrims will likely be part of a mission or camp in Mecca run by those travel agents.\n\nSome victim's families are blaming the Saudi authorities or the authorities of their own countries for not being organized enough or failing to provide enough shelter from the extreme heat.\n\nOthers have blamed those who arrived in Mecca unregistered. More than 171,000 unregistered pilgrims were identified as being in the country before Hajj began, Saudi Director of Public Security Mohammed bin Abdullah al-Bassami said earlier in the week. Saudi security services had previously launched a campaign to arrest anybody doing the Hajj illicitly.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims cannot access the same kinds of facilities -- air conditioning, water, shade, and misting or cooling centers -- that registered pilgrims can, which may have also caused casualties.\n\nDW spoke with a manager from a private Egyptian tour company who has been bringing Egyptian pilgrims to Mecca for several years now and who was in Saudi Arabia this week. The manager wouldn't give his name because he was not supposed to speak to media.\n\n\"The temperatures were high and people were noncompliant and also unaware [of how dangerous the heat was],\" he told DW by phone. \"Everyone just did what they wanted to and the whole thing was badly organized. Additionally there were not enough tents for everybody.\"\n\nThere definitely wasn't a stampede though, he said. \"People were happy to stand on Mount Arafat,\" he recounted.\n\n\"My point of view is that when people realized how hot it was and how intense the sun was, they should have avoided going up to the top,\" the pilgrimage manager explained, adding that many pilgrims don't realize you can simply stand on a lower slope to perform the ritual.\n\n\"Pilgrims need to be better educated and more aware,\" he continued. \"The state absolutely has obligations and bears responsibility. But the behavior of some [of the pilgrims] indicated a lack of awareness. And by that, I mean awareness regarding how to perform Hajj rituals. For example, the [Saudi] state is not able to place sunshades on the top of Mount Arafat.\"\n\nWhile the recriminations and the desperate pleas for help continue, one thing is certain: The Hajj is only going to get hotter.\n\nA 2019 study that asked whether Saudi attempts to cool down pilgrims during Hajj were successful concluded that while official measures did help, there was no escaping the fact that climate change was going to make the Hajj hotter, and therefore more dangerous, every year.", "source": {"uri": "dw.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Deutsche Welle"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-396117132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:36:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:36:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:30:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/explained/explained-global/why-hajj-deaths-saudi-9405014/", "title": "Who or what is responsible for Hajj deaths in Saudi Arabia?", "body": "Arabic-language social media has been flooded this week with shocking images from Saudi Arabia. The pictures and videos show people who were undertaking their once-in-a-lifetime Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca collapsed on the side of the road or slumped in wheelchairs, apparently close to death or dead. They are dressed in traditional pilgrim's white, their faces covered with cloths. In several pictures, corpses appear to have been left where they presumably collapsed.\n\nWhat started as a rumor on social media was confirmed as the weeklong Hajj pilgrimage ended: Hundreds of pilgrims have died in Saudi Arabia, evidently due to extremely high temperatures and lack of shelter or water.\n\nTemperatures in Mecca, Islam's holiest city, rose to 51.8 degrees Celsius (125 degrees Fahrenheit) during the course of the annual event, which started late last week.\n\nAround 1.8 million Muslims from all over the world had been expected in Saudi Arabia to perform Hajj. One of the world's largest religious gatherings, the Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam. Every Muslim who is able to is supposed to perform it at least once in their lifetime.\n\nSources in the Saudi Arabian Health Ministry told Reuters news agency they had recorded 2,700 cases of \"heat exhaustion.\" But they had been speaking before reports of deaths began to emerge. The country has not updated official statistics since then.\n\nAccording to AFP news agency, which has been tallying up fatalities via different sources and countries over the past few days, the death toll has topped 1,000.\n\nPilgrims from Egypt, Indonesia, Senegal, Jordan, Iran, Iraq, India and Tunisia have all died, their governments reported. A large number, likely over 300, came from Egypt. The Indonesian Health Ministry also reported over 140 nationals' deaths.\n\nOver the past years, Saudi authorities have tried to take measures to mitigate the impact of high summer temperatures on visitors by providing things like misting stations and water dispensers. Nevertheless, it is thought that most of the recent deaths are likely heat-related. Many of the pilgrims who perform Hajj are elderly, as undertaking the Hajj is something they want to do before they die.\n\nDesperate search for missing\n\nThe death toll may continue to rise. Friends and families are still searching Saudi hospitals or putting out calls for help on social media to try to find loved ones who arrived in Mecca but who are now missing.\n\n\"Honestly, Hajj this year was shameful,\" Ihlsa, a pilgrim from Aswan, in southern Egypt, who preferred not to give her full name, told DW via WhatsApp. \"It was very difficult, especially during the stoning. People were just collapsed on the ground.\"\n\nPart of the Hajj ritual involves pilgrims throwing stones at three walls, a symbolic form of \"stoning the devil.\"\n\n\"Several times I told the security personnel about a pilgrim who had fallen onto the ground,\" Ihlsa said. \"The distance to throw the stones was really too far and at the same time the sun was high, and it was so hot.\"\n\nWho or what is to blame?\n\nIn the pilgrims' home countries, a furious debate is taking place about who is to blame.\n\nTo do the Hajj, pilgrims need to have official permission from Saudi Arabia to enter the country. Because more Muslims want to come than there is space for, Saudi Arabia runs a quota system every year. Overcrowding and overheating have been serious problems in the past.\n\nThe trip to Saudi Arabia is usually facilitated by travel agencies, often linked to Muslim community organizations or mosques back home. They organize accommodation, food and transport in Mecca. Registered pilgrims will likely be part of a mission or camp in Mecca run by those travel agents.\n\nSome victim's families are blaming the Saudi authorities or the authorities of their own countries for not being organized enough or failing to provide enough shelter from the extreme heat.\n\nOthers have blamed those who arrived in Mecca unregistered. More than 171,000 unregistered pilgrims were identified as being in the country before Hajj began, Saudi Director of Public Security Mohammed bin Abdullah al-Bassami said earlier in the week. Saudi security services had previously launched a campaign to arrest anybody doing the Hajj illicitly.\n\nUnregistered pilgrims cannot access the same kinds of facilities -- air conditioning, water, shade, and misting or cooling centers -- that registered pilgrims can, which may have also caused casualties.\n\n'Not enough tents'\n\nDW spoke with a manager from a private Egyptian tour company who has been bringing Egyptian pilgrims to Mecca for several years now and who was in Saudi Arabia this week. The manager wouldn't give his name because he was not supposed to speak to media.\n\n\"The temperatures were high and people were noncompliant and also unaware [of how dangerous the heat was],\" he told DW by phone. \"Everyone just did what they wanted to and the whole thing was badly organized. Additionally there were not enough tents for everybody.\"\n\nThere definitely wasn't a stampede though, he said. \"People were happy to stand on Mount Arafat,\" he recounted.\n\n\"My point of view is that when people realized how hot it was and how intense the sun was, they should have avoided going up to the top,\" the pilgrimage manager explained, adding that many pilgrims don't realize you can simply stand on a lower slope to perform the ritual.\n\n\"Pilgrims need to be better educated and more aware,\" he continued. \"The state absolutely has obligations and bears responsibility. But the behavior of some [of the pilgrims] indicated a lack of awareness. And by that, I mean awareness regarding how to perform Hajj rituals. For example, the [Saudi] state is not able to place sunshades on the top of Mount Arafat.\"\n\nWhile the recriminations and the desperate pleas for help continue, one thing is certain: The Hajj is only going to get hotter.\n\nA 2019 study that asked whether Saudi attempts to cool down pilgrims during Hajj were successful concluded that while official measures did help, there was no escaping the fact that climate change was going to make the Hajj hotter, and therefore more dangerous, every year.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, Muslim pilgrims were wrapping up the Hajj pilgrimage in the deadly summer heat on Tuesday with the third day of the symbolic stoning of the devil, and the farewell circling around Kaaba in Mecca\n\nREPUBLIKA.CO.ID, JAKARTA -- The Saudi Arabian authority confirmed that most pilgrims who passed away during the current Hajj season were not part of their national Hajj delegation and came without a proper Hajj permit.\n\nSaudi's Ministry of Media explained that those individuals entered Saudi Arabia on tourism or visit visas months before the Hajj rituals began.\n\n\"These individuals remained in Mecca until the Hajj season and performed the pilgrimage without proper authorization,\" the Saudi ministry noted as per the statement received here on Thursday.\n\nThe Tunisian Foreign Ministry confirmed that most of their pilgrims who passed away while performing Hajj this year had arrived in Saudi Arabia not with a Hajj visa but only on a tourism, visit, or Umrah visa.\n\nLikewise, the Jordanian Foreign Ministry also reported that all Jordanian pilgrims who died or went missing were not part of the official Jordanian Hajj delegation, according to the Saudi ministry.\n\nThe Saudi authority confirmed that this year's Hajj season was marked by a significant increase in temperatures in Mecca, reaching 45 degrees Celsius.\n\nHowever, as the pilgrims were performing Hajj without proper authorization, they could not access the accommodation, food, or transportation services afforded to Hajj pilgrims to help them mitigate the effects of high temperatures.\n\n\"Consequently, they were exposed to the risks of heat exhaustion, sun exposure, and long (periods of) walking on rugged, unpaved paths not designated for pedestrians,\" according to the Saudi ministry.\n\n\"These conditions led to the unfortunate deaths of many. May their souls rest in peace,\" the ministry stated.\n\nAt least 550 pilgrims passed away while performing Hajj in Saudi Arabia due to the hot weather, according to AFP's report, as quoted from Sputnik.\n\nSome 323 out of the total casualties were reported to be Egyptian citizens. More than 40 pilgrims from Jordan and 35 from Tunisia have also died due to the scorching heat during this year's Hajj season.\n\nMeanwhile, the Indonesian Consulate General in Jidda reported on Monday (June 17) that at least 138 Indonesian pilgrims had passed away while performing Hajj. {"uri": "8185495549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:37:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:37:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:36:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://weather.com/news/news/2024-06-19-extreme-heat-hajj-pilgrimage-mecca", "title": "Hajj Pilgrimage Extreme Heat Leaves Hundreds Dead | Weather.com", "body": "Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility. The list offered no cause of death.\n\n(MORE: The Hidden Dangers Of A Heat Wave At Night)\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nTemperatures on Monday reached 116 degrees Fahrenheit in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city. Onlookers saw some people faint while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nAt the Grand Mosque in Mecca, temperatures reached 125 degrees on Monday though pilgrims had already left for Mina, authorities said.\n\n(MORE: Mystery Illness Sickens Grand Canyon Hikers)\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man collapsed to the ground when he heard the name of his mother among the dead. He cried for some time before grabbing his cellphone and calling a travel agent, shouting: \"He left her to die!\" The crowd tried to calm the man.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe AP could not independently confirm the causes of death for those bodies held at the complex. Saudi officials did not respond to questions seeking more information.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.", {"uri": "8187253418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "14:58:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T14:58:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T14:57:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://phys.org/news/2024-06-people-died-saudi-arabia-climate.html", "title": "Amid scorching heat, 900 people died in Saudi Arabia -- climate change has made the Hajj pilgrimage more risky", "body": "Each year, millions of Muslims from across the world embark on the Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia. The mass migration is unparalleled in scale, and pilgrims face numerous health hazards.\n\nMecca is considered the holiest city for Muslims. And Hajj is one of the Five Pillars of Islam, making it a mandatory religious duty for Muslims to perform at least once in their lifetime if they are physically and financially capable.\n\nThe 2024 Hajj pilgrimage has been overshadowed by disaster/tragedy, with the death of at least 900 pilgrims, mostly due to heat exhaustion and related complications.\n\nOne of the most devastating incidents occurred in 2015 during the ritual of \"Rami al-Jamarat\" in Mina, near Mecca. This ritual involves pilgrims throwing stones at pillars symbolizing the devil. On that day, overcrowding and the movement of large groups of pilgrims in opposite directions led to a deadly crowd crush. More than 2,400 pilgrims lost their lives, making it one of the deadliest disasters in the history of Hajj or any mass gathering.\n\nAnother mass casualty event occurred in 1990, in the Al-Ma'aisem pedestrian tunnel near Mecca, which led to the holy sites. A combination of ventilation failure and an enormous influx of pilgrims caused a suffocating crush inside the tunnel; 1,426 pilgrims died.\n\nThere have also been other incidents during the Hajj pilgrimage over the years. In 1994, a stampede near the Jamarat Bridge resulted in the deaths of around 270 pilgrims. The 1998 Hajj saw 118 pilgrims killed in another stampede.\n\nOver the past half-century, more than 9,000 people have died in mass religious gatherings, with more than 5,000 of these occurring during the Hajj in Saudi Arabia. India follows with at least 2,200 deaths across nearly 40 tragic events. These two countries are hotspots for such tragedies.\n\nWith millions of pilgrims converging in a confined area, the potential for overcrowding and crowd-crush accidents is high. This situation is worsened by the high emotion and passion associated with the pilgrimage. Pilgrims perform rituals with intense devotion and enthusiasm, which can sometimes lead to overexertion.\n\nAnother factor is the age of the pilgrims. Many are elderly, having saved for years to afford this spiritual journey. Their advanced age makes them particularly vulnerable to the harsh conditions and physical demands of the pilgrimage. The intense heat, prolonged periods of walking, and sheer physical strain of performing the rituals can exacerbate existing health issues and lead to new complications.\n\nThe extreme congestion of people also amplifies health risks, particularly from infectious diseases. Communicable diseases such as SARS, avian influenza and meningococcal disease have posed significant threats during Hajj in the past.\n\nA study documenting deaths and injuries at mass gatherings up to 2019 shows that, while the 1980s saw most fatalities at sporting events, such events are now rare, while fatalities during religious pilgrimages, particularly in India and Saudi Arabia, are becoming more common.\n\nWhile most Hajj fatalities have been due to crowd crushes and stampedes, a new threat has emerged: extreme climate. Saudi Arabia's climate can be brutal. During this year's pilgrimage, temperatures soared to 50\u00b0C.\n\nSaudi Arabia is warming at a rate 50% higher than the rest of the Northern Hemisphere. The decade from 2010 to 2019 was the warmest on record, with more frequent and severe heat waves. This rising temperature, combined with higher humidity, makes conditions increasingly unbearable without artificial cooling.\n\nThe timing of the Hajj pilgrimage, dictated by the lunar Islamic calendar, means it shifts approximately 10 to 11 days earlier each year in the Gregorian calendar. This means Hajj can occur in different seasons over a 33-year cycle. Currently, Hajj is being held during the summer months, leading to extreme heat risks.\n\nSaudi Arabia has also experienced an increase in extreme rainfall events in recent years, particularly towards the end of summer and into the fall. These torrential downpours and thunderstorms have caused significant flooding in regions such as Mecca and Jeddah.\n\nAs climate patterns continue to evolve, the occurrence of such rainfall could align with the Hajj season, creating additional hazards for pilgrims.\n\nUnlike concerts or sporting events, the Hajj pilgrimage cannot be rescheduled or relocated. Being outdoors is an integral part of Hajj.\n\nIt's crucial for pilgrims to perform the Hajj rituals correctly for their pilgrimage to be accepted. According to Islamic teachings, the Hajj must be conducted with precise adherence to its rituals and timings. Any deviation or omission can render the pilgrimage invalid.\n\nYet the extreme heat proved overwhelming, indicating more needs to be done. Educational campaigns can do more to raise awareness among (especially non-local) pilgrims and health-care workers about heat risks and preventive measures.\n\nThe introduction of new technologies such as smart bracelets for monitoring pilgrims' health could further enhance medical responses.", "source": {"uri": "phys.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Phys.org"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Saudi Hajj pilgrimage", "body": "Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials say as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died.\n\nHowever, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in al-Muaisem neighbourhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj.\n\nA medic who spoke to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine.\n\nThat medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity for the same reason said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility.\n\nDeaths are not uncommon at the Hajj, in which at times more than two million people travel to Saudi Arabia.\n\nThere have also been stampedes and epidemics through the pilgrimage's history.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income countries, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" according to an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health.\n\nCommunicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom save their entire lives for the pilgrimage and can be elderly with pre-existing health conditions, it said.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the fatalities to swell.\n\nSeveral countries the city, according to the Saudi National Centre for Meteorology.\n\nSome people fainted while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nMany Egyptians said they lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million from 22 countries and about 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man broke down when he heard his mother was among the dead.\n\nHe cried for some time before {"uri": "2024-06-395938601", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:02:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:02:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:55:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/hajj-pilgrim-deaths-surge-past-125551637.html", "title": "Hajj pilgrim deaths surge past 1,000 as Saudi Arabia faces extreme temperatures", "body": "The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is yet to comment on the official death toll, though reports suggest around 10 countries have reported 1,081 deaths during the annual pilgrimage. The\n\nHundreds of people lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, to claim their loved ones' bodies and find information about their missing family members.\n\nOutside the complex, an Egyptian man broke down when he heard his mother was among the dead. He cried for some time before reaching for his phone and calling their travel agent.\n\n\"He left her to die,\" he shouted, referring to the agent. The crowd tried to calm him down.\n\nAn official read out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India. Those who said they were relatives of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nAn Arab diplomat told news agency AFP that deaths among Egyptians alone had jumped to more than 650, with 630 of them being unregistered. Each year tens of thousands of pilgrims attempt the Hajj through other channels as they cannot afford official permits. Saudi authorities have said that it has clearing hundreds of thousands of unregistered pilgrims from Mecca this month.\n\nOut of around 150,000 pilgrims, Pakistan has recorded at least 58 deaths, a diplomat briefed on the tally told AFP. \"I think given the number of people, given the weather, this is just natural,\" the diplomat said.\n\nIndonesia, which had around 240,000 pilgrims, said the nation's death toll had reached 183 according to the ministry of religious affairs. They added 313 deaths were\n\nKhalid Bashir Bazaz, an Indian pilgrim, speaking near the Grand Mosque, said he \"saw a lot of people collapsing to the ground unconscious\".\n\nDeaths are not uncommon at the Hajj, There have also been stampedes and epidemics through the pilgrimage's history. Each year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, and illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom save their entire lives for the pilgrimage.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million from 22 countries, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of pounds on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number pilgrims makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year.\n\nBy 2029, the Hajj will occur in April, and in the next several years after that it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the Hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, though Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the {"uri": "8185656331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:33:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:33:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:33:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/06/19/hundreds-died-during-this-years-hajj-pilgrimage-in-saudi-arabia-amid-intense-heat-officials-say/", "title": "Hundreds Died During This Year's Hajj Pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia Amid Intense Heat, Officials Say", "body": "MECCA, Saudi Arabia -- Hundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials said Wednesday as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died. However, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in Al-Muaisem neighborhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj. A medic who spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine. That medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility.\n\nRelated Story: Putin Heading to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates for Talks With ...\n\nDeaths aren't uncommon at the Hajj, which has drawn at times over 2 million people to Saudi Arabia. There have been stampedes and epidemics through the pilgrimage's history.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income nations, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health said. Communicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom saved their entire lives for their trips and can be elderly with preexisting health conditions, the paper added.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the number of deaths to swell. Already, several countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nRelated Story: Muslims Celebrate the End of Ramadan With Eid al-Fitr\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an \"extreme danger threshold\" from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nIslam follows a lunar calendar, so the Hajj falls around 11 days earlier each year. In 2030, the Hajj will occur in April, and over the next several years it will fall in the winter, when temperatures are milder.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, an AP count showed. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/news/disaster-and-emergency/hundreds-reportedly-die-during-saudi-hajj-pilgrimage-c-15080792", "title": "'Hundreds' reportedly die during Saudi Hajj pilgrimage", "body": "'Hundreds' reportedly die during Saudi Hajj pilgrimageStaff WritersAPThu, 20 June 2024 4:59AM\n\nHundreds of people died during this year's Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia as the faithful faced intense high temperatures at Islamic holy sites in the desert kingdom, officials say as people tried to claim their loved ones' bodies.\n\nSaudi Arabia has not commented on the death toll amid the heat during the pilgrimage, required of every able Muslim once in their life, nor offered any causes for those who died.\n\nHowever, hundreds of people had lined up at the Emergency Complex in al-Muaisem neighbourhood in Mecca, trying to get information about their missing family members.\n\nOne list circulating online suggested at least 550 people died during the five-day Hajj.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nA medic who spoke to the Associated Press on condition of anonymity to discuss information not released publicly by the government said that the names listed appeared genuine.\n\nThat medic and another official who also spoke on condition of anonymity for the same reason said they believed at least 600 bodies were at the facility.\n\nDeaths are not uncommon at the Hajj, in which at times more than two million people travel to Saudi Arabia.\n\nThere have also been stampedes and epidemics through the pilgrimage's history.\n\nEach year, the Hajj draws hundreds of thousands of pilgrims from low-income countries, \"many of whom have had little, if any, pre-Hajj health care,\" according to an article in the April edition of the Journal of Infection and Public Health.\n\nCommunicable illnesses can spread among the gathered masses, many of whom save their entire lives for the pilgrimage and can be elderly with pre-existing health conditions, it said.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the fatalities to swell.\n\nSeveral countries have said some of their pilgrims died because of the heat that swept across the holy sites at Mecca, including Jordan and Tunisia.\n\nKhalid Bashir Bazaz, an Indian pilgrim, speaking near the Grand Mosque on Wednesday, said he \"saw a lot of people collapsing to the ground unconscious\" during this year's Hajj.\n\nTemperatures on Tuesday reached 47C in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Centre for Meteorology.\n\nSome people fainted while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nMany Egyptians said they lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million from 22 countries and about 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nOn Wednesday at the medical complex in Mecca, an Egyptian man broke down when he heard his mother was among the dead.\n\nHe cried for some time before grabbing his mobile phone and calling their travel agent.\n\n\"He left her to die,\" he shouted, referring to the agent.\n\nThe crowd tried to calm him down.\n\nSecurity appeared tight at the complex, with an official reading out names of the dead and the nationalities, which included people from Algeria, Egypt and India.\n\nThose who said they were kin of the dead were allowed inside to identify the deceased.\n\nThe Associated Press could not independently confirm the causes of death for the people whose bodies were held at the complex.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": "thewest.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "The West Australian"}, "authors": [], "https://images.thewest.com.au/publication/C-15080792/fc145f42bce89934f193e36f5f9b370532071087-16x9-x0y0w1280h720.jpg?imwidth=1200", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9660565", "eventUri": "eng-9660565", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1294117647058823, "wgt": 192, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8186691986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:12:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:12:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:11:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/06/20/550-hajj-pilgrims-die-mecca-temperatures-soar-past-50c-21070379/", "title": "At least 550 hajj pilgrims die after temperatures soar above 50\u00b0C at Mecca", "body": "At least 550 muslims making a pilgrimage to Mecca have died due to extreme heat.\n\nIt is believed 323 of those killed during the Hajj were Egyptian pilgrims, with around 60 Jordanians also succumbing to heat-related symptoms as temperatures in the Saudi Arabian holy land surged to over 50C throughout the week.\n\nDeaths are not uncommon at the Hajj, which has seen at times over 2 million people travel to Saudi Arabia. There have also been stampedes and epidemics throughout the pilgrimage's history.\n\nHowever, the number of dead this year suggests something caused the fatalities to swell. A local diplomat told reporters 'All of them died because of heat' except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, while Saudi authorities have reported treating more than 2,000 pilgrims suffering from heat stress over the weekend.\n\nTemperatures at the Grand Mosque in Mecca hit 51.8C on Monday, according to the Saudi national meteorology centre.\n\nAFP journalists following the Hajj on Monday also reported seeing pilgrims pouring bottles of water over their heads as volunteers handed out cold drinks and fast-melting chocolate ice-cream to help them keep cool.\n\nSpeaking near the Grand Mosque on Wednesday, Khalid Bashir Bazaz, an Indian pilgrim, said he 'saw a lot of people collapsing to the ground unconscious' in Mecca as people fainted while trying to perform the symbolic stoning of the devil.\n\nSaudi officials have attempted to curb the casualties by advising pilgrims to use umbrellas, avoid exposure to the sun and drink plenty of water as they make the pilgrimage.\n\nBut many of the hajj rituals, including the prayers on Mount Arafat which took place on Saturday, involve being outdoors for hours in the daytime.\n\nSome pilgrims described seeing motionless bodies on the roadside and ambulance services that appeared overwhelmed at times.\n\nMany Egyptians said they lost track of their loved ones in the heat and the crowds. More than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nMost countries have not specified how many deaths were heat-related, but on Tuesday, a diplomat tried to downplay the scale of the event by claiming the death toll had been boosted by a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims.\n\nSaudi Arabia has spent billions of dollars on crowd control and safety measures for those attending the annual five-day pilgrimage, but the sheer number of participants makes ensuring their safety difficult.\n\nClimate change could make the risk even greater. A 2019 study by experts at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that even if the world succeeds in mitigating the worst effects of climate change, the Hajj would be held in temperatures exceeding an 'extreme danger threshold' from 2047 to 2052, and from 2079 to 2086.\n\nA 2015 stampede in Mina during the hajj killed over 2,400 pilgrims, the deadliest incident to ever strike the pilgrimage, according to an AP count. Saudi Arabia has never acknowledged the full toll of the stampede. A separate crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque, which preceded the Mina disaster that same year, killed 111 people.\n\nThe second-deadliest incident at hajj was a 1990 stampede that killed 1,426 people.\n\nThe kingdom's ruling Al Saud family maintains a major influence in the Muslim world through its oil wealth and management of Islam's holiest sites.\n\nLike Saudi monarchs before him, King Salman has taken the title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, referring to the Grand Mosque in Mecca, home to the cube-shaped Kaaba that Muslims pray towards five times a day, and the Prophet's {"uri": "8185017736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:26:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:26:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:25:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/305980", "title": "Muslim pilgrims wrap up Hajj with final symbolic devil stoning", "body": "Muslim pilgrims wrapped up the Hajj in the deadly summer heat on Tuesday with the third day of the symbolic stoning of the devil, and the last circumambulation around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest site, in the city of Mecca.\n\nThe three-day stoning ritual in Mina, a desert site outside Mecca, is among the final rites of the pilgrimage and symbolizes the casting away of evil and sin. It started a day after pilgrims congregated on Saturday at a sacred hill known as Mount Arafat.\n\nThe final days of the annual Hajj coincide with Muslims around the world celebrating the Eid al-Adha holiday when the faithful with financial means commemorate Prophet Ibrahim's test of faith, when God ordered him to sacrifice his only son, by slaughtering livestock and animals and distributing the meat to the poor.\n\nThe Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam. Its rituals largely commemorate the accounts of Prophet Ibrahim and his son Prophet Ismail, Ismail's mother Hajar and the Prophet Muhammad, according to the Quran, Islam's holy book. In the Islamic version, God stayed his hand and Ismail was spared.\n\n\"I am reassured. I feel comfortable,\" Mejahed al-Mehrabi, a Yemeni pilgrim, told The Associated Press after he was done with the third day of the stoning ritual. \"Anyone who can visit the Grand Mosque (in Mecca) should do so.\"\n\nNigerian pilgrim Amir Omar was overjoyed once he finished his symbolic stoning. \"I am feeling very great that I perform one pillar of my religion,\" he said. \"I am feeling very grateful.\"\n\nThe burning sun and suffocating hot weather were relentless on Tuesday, with temperatures expected to reach 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Metrology.\n\nMany pilgrims, particularly elderly ones, collapsed and required medical assistance because of the heat. Dozens were also reported to have died from sunstroke.\n\nThe fatalities among pilgrims included at least 41 Jordanians and 35 Tunisians, according to Jordanian and Tunisian authorities. Local media in Egypt also reported dozens of fatalities among Egyptian pilgrims. Saudi authorities have yet to provide death tally during this year's Hajj.\n\nMany other pilgrims couldn't be accounted for while performing the rituals. Many Egyptians took to social medial to search for their relatives they believed were in Mount Arafat and in Mina. Some were found in hospitals around Mecca, after collapsing from the heat.\n\nAfter the third symbolic stoning Tuesday, pilgrims headed to Mecca to perform \"tawaf,\" the circling the Kaaba in the Grand Mosque counterclockwise seven times. That circumambulation, known as the Farewell Tawaf, marks the end of Hajj as pilgrims prepare to leave the holy city.\n\nOnce the Hajj is over, men are expected to shave their heads, and women to snip a lock of hair in a sign of renewal.\n\nMost of the pilgrims then leave Mecca for the city of Medina, about 340 kilometers (210 miles) away, to pray in the Prophet Muhammad's tomb, the Sacred Chamber.\n\nThe Sacred Chamber is part of the prophet's mosque, one of the three holiest sites in Islam, along with the Grand Mosque in Mecca and Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem.\n\nAll Muslims are required to make the Hajj once in their lives if they are physically and financially able to do so. Many wealthy Muslims make the pilgrimage more than once.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nThe 2024 pilgrimage came against the backdrop of the devastating Israel-Hamas war, which has pushed the Middle East to the brink of a regional conflict.\n\n\"I prayed first for Gaza then Yemen,\" said al-Mehrabi, the Yemeni pilgrim, referring to the war in the Palestinian enclave and the decade-old conflict in his home It started a day after pilgrims congregated Saturday at a sacred hill, known as Mount Arafat.\n\nThe final days of the annual Hajj coincide with Muslims around the world celebrating the Eid al-Adha holiday when Muslims with financial means commemorate Prophet Ibrahim's test of faith, when God ordered him to sacrifice his only son, by slaughtering livestock and animals and distributing the meat to the poor.\n\nThe Hajj is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. Its rituals largely commemorate the accounts of Prophet Ibrahim and his son Prophet Ismail, Ismail's mother Hajar and Prophet Muhammad, according to the Quran, Islam's holy book. In the Islamic version, God stayed his hand and Ismail was spared.\n\n\"I am reassured. Dozens were also reported dead from sunstroke. They included at least 41 Jordanian pilgrims who will be buried in Saudi Arabia, according to Jordan's Foreign Ministry.\n\nMany other pilgrims couldn't be accounted for while performing the rituals. Many Egyptians took to social medial to search for their relatives in Mount Arafat and Mina. Some were found in hospitals around Mecca after collapsing from the heatwave.\n\nAfter the third symbolic stoning Tuesday, pilgrims headed to Mecca to perform \"tawaf,\" circling the Kaaba in the Grand Mosque counterclockwise seven times. That circumambulation, known as the Farewell Tawaf, marks the end of Hajj as pilgrims prepare to leave the holy city.\n\nOnce the Hajj is over, men are expected to shave their heads, and women to snip a lock of hair in a sign of renewal.\n\nMost of the pilgrims then leave Mecca for the city of Medina, about 210 miles away, to pray in Prophet Muhammad's tomb, the Sacred Chamber.\n\nThe Sacred Chamber tomb is part of the prophet's mosque, one of the three holiest sites in Islam, along with the Grand Mosque in Mecca and the Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem.\n\nAll Muslims are required to make the Hajj once in their lives if they are physically and financially able to do so. Many wealthy Muslims make the pilgrimage more than once.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nThe 2014 pilgrimage came against the backdrop of the devastating Israel-Hamas war, which has pushed the Middle East to the brink of a {"uri": "2024-06-393311137", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "10:25:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T10:25:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T10:22:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/muslim-pilgrims-warp-hajj-final-symbolic-stoning-devil-111207566", "title": "Muslim pilgrims wrap up Hajj with final symbolic stoning of the devil and circling of Kaaba", "body": "Muslim pilgrims are wrapping up the Hajj, or pilgrimage, in the deadly summer heat with the third day of the symbolic stoning of the devil, and the last circumambulation around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest site, in the city of Mecca\n\nMINA, Saudi Arabia -- Muslim pilgrims are wrapping up the Hajj, or pilgrimage, in the deadly summer heat on Tuesday with the third day of the symbolic stoning of the devil, and the last circumambulation around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest site, in the city of Mecca.\n\nThe three-day stoning ritual in Mina, a desert site outside Mecca, is among the final rites of the Hajj, and symbolizes the casting away of evil and sin. It started a day after pilgrims congregated Saturday at a sacred hill, known as Mount Arafat.\n\nThe final days of the annual Hajj coincide with Muslims around the world celebrating the Eid al-Adha holiday when Muslims with financial means commemorate Prophet Ibrahim's test of faith, when God ordered him to sacrifice his only son, by slaughtering livestock and animals and distributing the meat to the poor.\n\nThe Hajj is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. Its rituals largely commemorate the accounts of Prophet Ibrahim and his son Prophet Ismail, Ismail's mother Hajar and Prophet Muhammad, according to the Quran, Islam's holy book. In the Islamic version, God stayed his hand and Ismail was spared.\n\n\"I am reassured. I feel comfortable,\" Mejahed al-Mehrabi, a Yemeni pilgrim, told The Associated Press after he was done with the third day of the stoning ritual. \"Anyone who can visit the Grand Mosque (in Mecca) should do so.\"\n\nThe burning sun and suffocating hot weather remained Tuesday, with temperatures, expected to reach 47 degrees Celsius (116.6 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Metrology.\n\nMany pilgrims, particularly elderly ones, were seen collapsed and in need of medical assistance because of the heat. Dozens, including 14 from Jordan, were also reported dead.\n\nAfter the symbolic stoning, pilgrims head to Mecca to perform \"tawaf,\" or circumambulation, circling the Kaaba in the Grand Mosque counterclockwise seven times. That circumambulation, known as the Farewell Tawaf, marks the end of Hajj as pilgrims prepare to leave the holy city.\n\nOnce the Hajj is over, men are expected to shave their heads, and women to snip a lock of hair in a sign of renewal.\n\nMost of the pilgrims then leave Mecca for the city of Medina, about 340 kilometers (210 miles) away, to pray in Prophet Muhammad's tomb, the Sacred Chamber.\n\nThe Sacred Chamber tomb is part of the prophet's mosque, one of the three holiest sites in Islam, along with the Grand Mosque in Mecca and the Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem.\n\nAll Muslims are required to make the Hajj once in their lives if they are physically and financially able to do so. Many wealthy Muslims make the pilgrimage more than once.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nThe 2014 pilgrimage came against the backdrop of the devastating Israel-Hamas war, which has pushed the Middle East to the brink of a regional conflict.\n\n\"I prayed first for Gaza then Yemen,\" said al-Mehrabi, the Yemeni pilgrim, referring to the war between Israel and Hamas in the Palestinian enclave and the decade-old conflict It started a day after pilgrims congregated on Saturday at a sacred hill known as Mount Arafat.\n\nThe final days of the annual Hajj coincide with Muslims around the world celebrating the Eid al-Adha holiday when the faithful with financial means commemorate Prophet Ibrahim's test of faith, when God ordered him to sacrifice his only son, by slaughtering livestock and animals and distributing the meat to the poor.\n\nThe Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam. Its rituals largely commemorate the accounts of Prophet Ibrahim and his son Prophet Ismail, Ismail's mother Hajar and the Prophet Muhammad, according to the Quran, Islam's holy book. In the Islamic version, God stayed his hand and Ismail was spared.\n\n\"I am reassured. I feel comfortable,\" Mejahed al-Mehrabi, a Yemeni pilgrim, told The Associated Press (AP) after he was done with the third day of the stoning ritual. \"Anyone who can visit the Grand Mosque (in Mecca) should do so.\"\n\nNigerian pilgrim Amir Omar was overjoyed once he finished his symbolic stoning. \"I am feeling very great that I performed one pillar of my religion,\" he said. \"I am feeling very grateful.\"\n\nThe burning sun and suffocating hot weather were relentless on Tuesday, with temperatures expected to reach 47 degrees Celsius (117 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Metrology.\n\nMany pilgrims, particularly elderly ones, collapsed and required medical assistance because of the heat. Dozens were also reported to have died from sunstroke.\n\nThe fatalities among pilgrims included at least 41 Jordanians and 35 Tunisians, according to Jordanian and Tunisian authorities. Local media in Egypt also reported dozens of fatalities among Egyptian pilgrims. Saudi authorities have yet to provide a death tally during this year's Hajj.\n\nMany other pilgrims couldn't be accounted for while performing the rituals. Many Egyptians took to social media to search for their relatives they believed were in Mount Arafat and Mina. Some were found in hospitals around Mecca, after collapsing from the heat.\n\nAfter the third symbolic stoning Tuesday, pilgrims headed to Mecca to perform \"tawaf,\" the circling of the Kaaba in the Grand Mosque counterclockwise seven times. That circumambulation, known as the Farewell Tawaf, marks the end of Hajj as pilgrims prepare to leave the holy city.\n\nOnce the Hajj is over, men are expected to shave their heads and women to snip a lock of hair in a sign of renewal.\n\nMost of the pilgrims then leave Mecca for the city of Medina, about 340 kilometers (210 miles) away, to pray in the Prophet Muhammad's tomb, the Sacred Chamber.\n\nThe Sacred Chamber is part of the Prophet's Mosque, one of the three holiest sites in Islam, along with the Grand Mosque in Mecca and Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem.\n\nAll Muslims are required to make the Hajj once in their lives if they are physically and financially able to do so. Many wealthy Muslims make the pilgrimage more than once.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to the Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nThe 2024 pilgrimage came against the backdrop of the devastating Israeli-Palestinian conflict, which has pushed the Middle {"uri": "8186284231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "04:03:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T04:03:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T04:02:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "http://theconversation.com/amid-scorching-heat-900-people-died-this-week-in-saudi-arabia-climate-change-has-made-the-hajj-pilgrimage-more-risky-232836", "title": "Amid scorching heat, 900 people died this week in Saudi Arabia. Climate change has made the Hajj pilgrimage more risky", "body": "UNSW Sydney provides funding as a member of The Conversation AU.\n\nEach year, millions of Muslims from across the world embark on the Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca in Saudi Arabia. The mass migration is unparalleled in scale, and pilgrims face numerous health hazards.\n\nMecca is considered the holiest city for Muslims. And Hajj is one of the Five Pillars of Islam, making it a mandatory religious duty for Muslims to perform at least once in their lifetime if they are physically and financially capable.\n\nThe 2024 Hajj pilgrimage has been overshadowed by disaster/tragedy, with the death of at least 900 pilgrims, mostly due to heat exhaustion and related complications.\n\nThis isn't the first deadly disaster during Hajj\n\nOne of the most devastating incidents occurred in 2015 during the ritual of \"Rami al-Jamarat\" in Mina, near Mecca. This ritual involves pilgrims throwing stones at pillars symbolising the devil. On that day, overcrowding and the movement of large groups of pilgrims in opposite directions led to a deadly crowd crush. More than 2,400 pilgrims lost their lives, making it one of the deadliest disasters in the history of Hajj or any mass gathering.\n\nAnother mass casualty event occurred in 1990, in the Al-Ma'aisem pedestrian tunnel near Mecca, which led to the holy sites. A combination of ventilation failure and an enormous influx of pilgrims caused a suffocating crush inside the tunnel; 1,426 pilgrims died.\n\nThere have also been other incidents during the Hajj pilgrimage over the years. In 1994, a stampede near the Jamarat Bridge resulted in the deaths of around 270 pilgrims. The 1998 Hajj saw 118 pilgrims killed in another stampede.\n\nOver the past half-century, more than 9,000 people have died in mass religious gatherings, with more than 5,000 of these occurring during the Hajj in Saudi Arabia. India follows with at least 2,200 deaths across nearly 40 tragic events. These two countries are hotspots for such tragedies.\n\nWhy is the Hajj pilgrimage so risky?\n\nWith millions of pilgrims converging in a confined area, the potential for overcrowding and crowd-crush accidents is high. This situation is worsened by the high emotion and passion associated with the pilgrimage. Pilgrims perform rituals with intense devotion and enthusiasm, which can sometimes lead to overexertion.\n\nAnother factor is the age of the pilgrims. Many are elderly, having saved for years to afford this spiritual journey. Their advanced age makes them particularly vulnerable to the harsh conditions and physical demands of the pilgrimage. The intense heat, prolonged periods of walking, and sheer physical strain of performing the rituals can exacerbate existing health issues and lead to new complications.\n\nThe extreme congestion of people also amplifies health risks, particularly from infectious diseases. Communicable diseases such as SARS, avian influenza and meningococcal disease have posed significant threats during Hajj in the past.\n\nHigh temperatures make mass gatherings riskier\n\nA study documenting deaths and injuries at mass gatherings up to 2019 shows that, while the 1980s saw most fatalities at sporting events, such events are now rare, while fatalities during religious pilgrimages, particularly in India and Saudi Arabia, are becoming more common.\n\nWhile most Hajj fatalities have been due to crowd crushes and stampedes, a new threat has emerged: extreme climate. Saudi Arabia's climate can be brutal. During this year's pilgrimage, temperatures soared to 50\u00b0C.\n\nSaudi Arabia is warming at a rate 50% higher than the rest of the Northern Hemisphere. The decade from 2010 to 2019 was the warmest on record, with more frequent and severe heatwaves. This rising temperature, combined with higher humidity, makes conditions increasingly unbearable without artificial cooling.\n\nThe timing of the Hajj pilgrimage, dictated by the lunar Islamic calendar, means it shifts approximately 10 to 11 days earlier each year in the Gregorian calendar. This means Hajj can occur in different seasons over a 33-year cycle. Currently, Hajj is being held during the summer months, leading to extreme heat risks.\n\nSaudi Arabia has also experienced an increase in extreme rainfall events in recent years, particularly towards the end of summer and into the fall. These torrential downpours and thunderstorms have caused significant flooding in regions such as Mecca and Jeddah.\n\nAs climate patterns continue to evolve, the occurrence of such rainfall could align with the Hajj season, creating additional hazards for pilgrims.\n\nWhat can be done to mitigate the risks?\n\nUnlike concerts or sporting events, the Hajj pilgrimage cannot be rescheduled or relocated. Being outdoors is an integral part of Hajj.\n\nIt's crucial for pilgrims to perform the Hajj rituals correctly for their pilgrimage to be accepted. According to Islamic teachings, the Hajj must be conducted with precise adherence to its rituals and timings. Any deviation or omission can render the pilgrimage invalid.\n\nThe Saudi Ministry of Health has implemented various measures, including encouraging vaccinations, health checks and educational campaigns urging pilgrims to stay hydrated, use umbrellas and avoid prolonged sun exposure.\n\nThe ministry deployed thousands of paramedics and set up field hospitals to manage the crisis. Cooling measures such as misting systems and portable water stations were used.\n\nYet the extreme heat proved overwhelming, indicating more needs to be done. Educational campaigns can do more to raise awareness among (especially non-local) pilgrims and health-care workers about heat risks and preventive measures.\n\nThe introduction of new technologies such as smart bracelets for monitoring pilgrims' health could further enhance medical responses.", "source": {"uri": "theconversation.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Conversation"}, "authors": Dozens were also reported to have died from sunstroke.\n\nTwo officials who spoke to the Associated Press on the condition of anonymity said that around 600 deaths had been confirmed at a medical complex in Mecca.\n\nSaudi authorities have yet to provide a death tally during this year's Hajj.\n\nDeaths are not uncommon at the Hajj, which throughout its history has also been impacted by stampedes and epidemics.\n\nThe fatalities among pilgrims this year included at least 41 Jordanians and 35 Tunisians, according to officials from both countries.\n\nLocal media in Egypt also reported dozens of fatalities among Egyptian pilgrims. Many Egyptians took to social media to search for relatives they believed were missing.\n\nSome were found in hospitals around Mecca, after collapsing from the heat, while many others could not be accounted for while performing the rituals.\n\nThe Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam, and all Muslims must make the pilgrimage to Mecca at least once in their life.\n\nOnce the Hajj is over, men are expected to shave their heads, and women to snip a lock of hair in a sign of renewal.\n\nMost of the pilgrims then leave Mecca for the city of Medina, around 210 miles away, to pray in the Prophet Muhammad's tomb, the Sacred Chamber.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed the Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens {"uri": "2024-06-395684087", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "09:36:03", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T09:36:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:35:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/1234/525714/Egypt/Foreign-Affairs/Egypt-repatriating-deceased-Egyptian-pilgrims-and-.aspx", "title": "Egypt repatriating deceased Egyptian pilgrims and locating missing ones", "body": "Muslim pilgrims perform the farewell circumambulation or tawaf , circling seven times around the Kaaba, at the Grand Mosque in the holy city of Mecca at the end of the annual hajj pilgrimage. AFP\n\nIndividuals with relatives missing in Mecca, Medina, and the holy pilgrimage sites, or those seeking repatriation of deceased relatives, are advised to contact the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.\n\nThey can head directly to the ministry's headquarters at 7 Lazoghly Street, first floor in Cairo's Garden City district, Isis building.\n\nThey can reach the operations room through the following phone numbers: (27923050 - 27923060 - 27942782 - 01006638814).\n\nThis year's Hajj season has witnessed the deaths of at least 550 pilgrims, including 323 Egyptians, due to sweltering temperatures, diplomats told Agence France-Presse (AFP) on Tuesday.\n\nThe bodies of the victims are currently held in the hospital morgue in Mecca.\n\nMeanwhile, an AFP tally estimates the number of victims from multiple countries at 577 as of Tuesday.\n\n\"All of them (the Egyptians) died because of heat\" except for one who sustained fatal injuries during a minor crowd crush, one of the diplomats said.\n\nThe Hajj this year, 1445 AH, is being performed by nearly 2 million pilgrims amid scorching heat. Temperatures neared 52 degrees Celsius in Mecca on Monday, according to Saudi Arabia's National Center for Meteorology (NCM).\n\nOne of the diplomats who spoke to AFP said the presence of a large number of unregistered Egyptian pilgrims during this season has \"absolutely\" contributed to the Egyptian death toll as this led to the collapse of provided services.\n\n\"Irregular pilgrims caused great chaos in the Egyptian pilgrims' camps, causing the collapse of services,\" said an Egyptian official supervising the country's Hajj mission.\n\n\"The pilgrims went without food, water, or air conditioning for a long time.\" They died \"from the heat because most people had no place\" to take shelter.\n\nSaudi Arabia annually develops major works to provide cooling systems and air-conditioned facilities and tents for Hajj pilgrims in Mecca and other holy sites.\n\nSaudi officials have also advised pilgrims to stick to umbrellas, drink plenty of fluids, and avoid exposure to direct sun during the hottest hours of the day whenever possible.\n\nMeanwhile, Saudi authorities have boosted their efforts in fighting unregistered Hajj and officials said that they have cleared over 300,000 pilgrims from Mecca due to not possessing Hajj permits.\n\nThe Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and is obligatory on able-bodied Muslims who have the financial means to perform it.\n\nMany Muslims aspire to fulfil their dream of performing Hajj, where they touch the holy Kaaba, visit the Prophet Muhammad's grave in Medina, and ascend Mount Arafat, retracing the footsteps of the Prophet from over 1,400 years ago.\n\nHowever, with substantial Hajj expenses nowadays, it has increasingly become inaccessible for many people.\n\nMany Muslim scholars have urged Muslims worldwide to abide by the Saudi measures in organizing Hajj to ensure their safety and to avoid hurting others. They also advised people to refrain from unregistered Hajj.\n\nAccording to Saudi authorities, around 1.8 million pilgrims, including 1.6 million from abroad, perform the Hajj annually. Over the past few days, many pilgrims have been reported missing.\n\nThe Egyptian consulate in Jeddah has formed an operations chamber operating round the clock to receive phone calls on (00966565702002) from citizens who lost contact with their relatives in the pilgrimage sites during this Hajj season, said the foreign ministry yesterday.\n\nThe foreign ministry added that it \"is exerting intensive efforts, in coordination with the Saudi authorities, to follow up on the search for Egyptian citizens missing while performing the Hajj rituals.\"\n\nEgypt's tourism Hajj mission reported on Tuesday that it has managed to locate 142 lost Egyptian pilgrims, while one is still missing, according to the Egyptian state's news agency MENA.\n\nAccording to media figures, around 56,000 Egyptian pilgrims are performing Hajj this year.", "source": {"uri": "english.ahram.org.eg", "dataType": "news", "title": "\u062c\u0631\u064a\u062f\u0629 {"uri": "2024-06-393705024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "16:07:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T16:07:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T06:01:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jun/18/muslim-pilgrims-end-hajj-with-final-symbolic-stoni/", "title": "Muslim pilgrims wrap up Hajj with final symbolic stoning of the devil and circling of Kaaba", "body": "MINA, Saudi Arabia -- Muslim pilgrims are wrapping up the Hajj, or pilgrimage, in the deadly summer heat on Tuesday with the third day of the symbolic stoning of the devil, and the last circumambulation around the Kaaba, Islam's holiest site, in the city of Mecca.\n\nThe three-day stoning ritual in Mina, a desert site outside Mecca, is among the final rites of the Hajj, and symbolizes the casting away of evil and sin. It started a day after pilgrims congregated Saturday at a sacred hill, known as Mount Arafat.\n\nThe final days of the annual Hajj coincide with Muslims around the world celebrating the Eid al-Adha holiday when Muslims with financial means commemorate Prophet Ibrahim's test of faith, when God ordered him to sacrifice his only son, by slaughtering livestock and animals and distributing the meat to the poor.\n\nThe Hajj is one of the Five Pillars of Islam. Its rituals largely commemorate the accounts of Prophet Ibrahim and his son Prophet Ismail, Ismail's mother Hajar and Prophet Muhammad, according to the Quran, Islam's holy book. In the Islamic version, God stayed his hand and Ismail was spared.\n\n\"I am reassured. I feel comfortable,\" Mejahed al-Mehrabi, a Yemeni pilgrim, told The Associated Press after he was done with the third day of the stoning ritual. \"Anyone who can visit the Grand Mosque (in Mecca) should do so.\"\n\nThe burning sun and suffocating hot weather remained Tuesday, with temperatures, expected to reach 47 degrees Celsius (116.6 degrees Fahrenheit) in Mecca and the sacred sites in and around the city, according to the Saudi National Center for Metrology.\n\nMany pilgrims, particularly elderly ones, were seen collapsed and in need of medical assistance because of the heat. Dozens, including 14 from Jordan, were also reported dead.\n\nAfter the symbolic stoning, pilgrims head to Mecca to perform \"tawaf,\" or circumambulation, circling the Kaaba in the Grand Mosque counterclockwise seven times. That circumambulation, known as the Farewell Tawaf, marks the end of Hajj as pilgrims prepare to leave the holy city.\n\nOnce the Hajj is over, men are expected to shave their heads, and women to snip a lock of hair in a sign of renewal.\n\nMost of the pilgrims then leave Mecca for the city of Medina, about 340 kilometers (210 miles) away, to pray in Prophet Muhammad's tomb, the Sacred Chamber.\n\nThe Sacred Chamber tomb is part of the prophet's mosque, one of the three holiest sites in Islam, along with the Grand Mosque in Mecca and the Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem.\n\nAll Muslims are required to make the Hajj once in their lives if they are physically and financially able to do so. Many wealthy Muslims make the pilgrimage more than once.\n\nMore than 1.83 million Muslims performed Hajj in 2024, including more than 1.6 million pilgrims from 22 countries, and around 222,000 Saudi citizens and residents, according to Saudi Hajj authorities.\n\nThe 2014 pilgrimage came against the backdrop of the devastating Israel-Hamas war, which has pushed the Middle East to the brink of a regional conflict.\n\n\"I prayed first for Gaza then Yemen,\" said al-Mehrabi, the Yemeni pilgrim, referring to the war between Israel and Hamas in the Palestinian enclave and the decade-old conflict in his home country.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "samy_magdy@washingtontimes.com", "name": "Samy Magdy", "type":
